sentence1: The drain is clogged with hair. It has to be cleaned.
sentence2: The hair has to be cleaned.

sentence1: Jane knocked on Susan's door but she did not answer.
Beth didn't get angry with Sally, who had cut her off, because she stopped and counted to ten.
sentence2: Sally stopped and counted to ten.

sentence1: No one joins Facebook to be sad and lonely. But a new study from the University of Wisconsin psychologist George Lincoln argues that that's exactly how it makes us feel.
sentence2: That's exactly how Facebook makes us feel.

sentence1: The man couldn't lift his son because he was so heavy.
Susan knew that Ann's son had been in a car accident, so she told her about it.
When Tommy dropped his ice cream, Timmy giggled, so father gave him a stern look.
sentence2: Father gave Timmy a stern look.

sentence1: There is a pillar between me and the stage, and I can't see around it.
sentence2: I can't see around the pillar.

sentence1: Look! There is a minnow swimming right below that duck! It had better get away to safety fast!
sentence2: The duck had better get away to safety fast!

sentence1: Bernard, who had not told the government official that he was less than 21 when he filed for a homestead claim, did not consider that he had done anything dishonest. Still, anyone who knew that he was 19 years old could take his claim away from him.
sentence2: Anyone who knew that he was 19 years old could take his claim away from anyone.
